context: Together with caesium and gold (both <a4_0><b8_0>yellow<b8_0/><a4_0/>), and osmium (bluish), copper is one of only <a0_0><b5_0>four<b5_0/><a0_0/> elemental metals with a natural color other than gray or silver. Pure copper is <a1_0><b6_0>orange-red<b6_0/><a1_0/> and acquires a <a2_0><b7_0>reddish tarnish<b7_0/><a2_0/> when exposed to air. The characteristic color of copper results from the electronic transitions between the filled 3d and half-empty 4s atomic shells – the energy difference between these shells is such that it corresponds to <a3_0>orange light<a3_0/>. The same mechanism accounts for the yellow color of gold and caesium.
